persona.name: Linda Marie Swenson

occupation.title: Lead Cook
occupation.organization: Lutheran Home Assisted Living Center, Decorah, Iowa
occupation.description: Linda is the lead cook at a mid-sized assisted living facility, responsible for planning and preparing three meals daily for 60+ residents, many with dietary restrictions. She manages a small team of kitchen staff, oversees inventory and ordering, and ensures compliance with state and federal food safety regulations. Her work involves early mornings, standing for long periods, and adapting recipes for residents' needs. She is known for her reliability, attention to detail, and ability to keep the kitchen running smoothly even during staff shortages. Linda is also the go-to person for special event catering at the facility, often baking cakes and cookies for birthdays and holidays. She occasionally fills in at a local diner on weekends for extra income.

persona.residence: Outside Decorah, Iowa, USA (rural farmstead, population <1,000)
persona.education: Decorah High School graduate, class of 1993. Completed a two-year culinary certificate at Northeast Iowa Community College, specializing in institutional food preparation and safety. Regularly attends continuing education workshops on food safety, nutrition, and menu planning through her employer and local extension office.
long_term_goals: To qualify for the Boston Marathon before age 55, improving her personal best by at least 10 minutes.
To maintain good health and mobility into her senior years, avoiding chronic conditions common in her family.
To save enough for a comfortable retirement with her husband, ideally remaining on their family land.
To see her children graduate college and settle nearby.
To continue serving as a role model for healthy living and discipline in her church and community.
To eventually open a small, home-based bakery business after retirement, focusing on Scandinavian pastries.
To deepen her involvement in the local Lutheran church, possibly taking on a leadership or teaching role.
persona.style: Linda speaks with a soft Midwestern accent, her vowels slightly drawn out and her tone warm but reserved. She is polite, rarely swears, and uses colloquial expressions common in rural Iowa ('you betcha', 'might as well', 'oh for cute'). She dresses practically—running shoes, jeans or athletic leggings, and layered tops, often with a windbreaker or fleece. At work, she wears a plain uniform and hairnet. She is punctual, methodical, and prefers to listen before speaking. In groups, she is friendly but not the center of attention, often offering practical advice or a gentle joke. She avoids confrontation, but stands her ground on matters of principle. Her body language is open but modest; she rarely gestures widely, and her laughter is quiet. She is more formal with strangers, but becomes warmer and more relaxed with those she knows well. She is known for her reliability and for remembering small details about others’ lives.

traits: Highly conscientious: Linda is organized, punctual, and detail-oriented, both at work and in her running.
Low openness: She prefers familiar routines, traditional recipes, and tried-and-true training plans.
Reliable: Friends and coworkers know they can count on her to follow through.
Self-disciplined: She rarely skips a workout or cheats on her budget.
Reserved: She is friendly but not effusive, and keeps her private life private.
Pragmatic: She values practical solutions over abstract ideas.
Loyal: She maintains long-term friendships and is deeply committed to her family and church.
Modest: She downplays her achievements and avoids drawing attention to herself.
Emotionally steady: She rarely shows anger or distress in public, preferring to process emotions privately.
Traditional: She values customs, rituals, and the familiar, and is slow to adopt new trends.
Cautious: She avoids unnecessary risks, both in running (injury prevention) and in life.
Supportive: She encourages others, especially new runners or coworkers, but is not pushy.
Low tolerance for disorder: She becomes anxious if her routines are disrupted.
Mildly competitive: She enjoys racing and improving her times, but is not cutthroat.
Skeptical of fads: She questions new diets, training gadgets, or social trends until proven.

big_five.openness: Low. Prefers routine, tradition, and familiar experiences; cautious about new ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Very high. Exceptionally organized, disciplined, and reliable.
big_five.extraversion: Low to moderate. Enjoys small group interactions and familiar faces, but avoids large crowds and parties.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate. Kind and supportive, but can be blunt or stubborn when her values are challenged.
big_five.neuroticism: Low. Generally calm, emotionally stable, and able to manage stress effectively.

interests: Distance running (10K, half-marathon, marathon), with a focus on performance and injury prevention.
Cooking and baking, especially Scandinavian and Midwestern comfort foods.
Outdoor activities: hiking, camping, fishing, and gardening.
Reading practical non-fiction (cookbooks, running guides, local history).
Listening to country and Christian music, especially while running or cooking.
Attending church events and volunteering for community suppers.
Watching televised track and field events, especially the Olympics.
Following local high school sports teams.
Birdwatching, especially in spring and fall.
Knitting and simple crafts during winter evenings.
Home canning and preserving produce from her garden.
Participating in local 5K and 10K races, often as a volunteer or organizer.
Spending time with family, especially her grandchildren.
Visiting local farmers’ markets and county fairs.
Collecting vintage kitchenware and cookbooks.
Listening to NPR or local radio for news and weather.
Enjoying quiet evenings at home with her husband.
Watching reruns of classic sitcoms (e.g., 'The Andy Griffith Show', 'Golden Girls').
Enjoying bland foods: mashed potatoes, plain chicken, oatmeal, white bread, and mild cheeses.
Avoiding spicy foods, strong flavors, and unfamiliar cuisines.
likes: Early morning runs on gravel roads, especially when the sun is rising.
The feeling of accomplishment after a long run or race.
Well-worn running shoes and gear that fits just right.
Homemade bread, cinnamon rolls, and lefse.
The smell of fresh-cut hay and rain on soil.
Organizing her kitchen and pantry.
Quiet time for prayer and reflection.
The camaraderie of local running groups.
Seasonal changes, especially the first snow and the first warm day of spring.
Simple, functional home decor.
Handwritten notes and cards.
Watching deer and wild turkeys from her kitchen window.
The sound of gravel crunching underfoot.
A well-balanced checkbook and a clear budget.
Volunteering at church bake sales.
Listening to her husband’s stories about farming.
Seeing her children succeed and make good choices.
The annual family reunion picnic.
A hot cup of weak coffee with cream.
The satisfaction of a well-executed meal service at work.
dislikes: Crowded races or big city marathons.
Trendy diets (e.g., keto, paleo) and expensive supplements.
Being pressured to try new foods or activities.
Gossip and negativity in the workplace.
People who don’t follow through on commitments.
Running in extreme heat or humidity.
Feeling out of control or unprepared.

beliefs: Faith in God is central to her life; she attends Lutheran services weekly and prays daily.
Believes in the importance of hard work, self-reliance, and personal responsibility.
Values family above all, seeing it as the foundation of a good life.
Thinks the federal budget deficit is a serious concern and worries about the country’s financial future.
Believes the state of moral values in the country is declining, especially among younger generations.
Supports lower taxes and limited government intervention in daily life.
Believes in free market capitalism and the value of entrepreneurship.
Prefers local businesses and products over large corporations or imports.
Sees traditional gender roles as generally positive, but values women’s independence and work outside the home.
Believes in the sanctity of marriage and the importance of fidelity.
Views regular physical activity as a moral and practical duty.
Believes in budgeting, saving, and living within one’s means.
Is skeptical of government welfare programs, preferring community-based support.
Believes in the right to bear arms, but supports responsible gun ownership.
Thinks rural communities are the backbone of America.
Believes in respecting elders and learning from their experience.
Sees volunteering and service as essential to a meaningful life.
Believes in the power of prayer and the importance of forgiveness.
Is wary of rapid social change and prefers gradual adaptation.
Believes in the importance of education, but values practical skills over academic credentials.
Supports local law enforcement and first responders.
Believes in the importance of voting and civic engagement.
Is skeptical of mainstream media and prefers local news sources.
Believes in the value of tradition, especially in food, holidays, and rituals.
Sees running as a metaphor for life: discipline, perseverance, and steady progress.
Believes in the importance of rest and Sabbath observance.
Is cautious about new technology, especially in health and food.
Believes in the dignity of all work, regardless of status.
Thinks children should be taught respect, manners, and self-control.
Believes in the healing power of nature and time outdoors.
Is concerned about the future of small farms and rural life.
Believes in supporting neighbors in times of need.
Is wary of debt and avoids borrowing whenever possible.
Believes in the importance of honesty, even when it’s uncomfortable.
Sees herself as a steward of her health, her family, and her community.
Believes that discipline in running and in life leads to freedom.
Is skeptical of 'miracle' health products and quick fixes.
Believes in the importance of a good night’s sleep.
Thinks that everyone should know how to cook basic meals.
Believes that faith and science can coexist.
skills: Expert in large-scale meal planning and preparation, including adapting recipes for dietary restrictions (low sodium, diabetic, gluten-free).
Efficient in time management, able to coordinate multiple tasks under pressure.
Proficient in food safety protocols and kitchen sanitation.
Experienced in baking breads, pastries, and traditional Scandinavian desserts.
Skilled in budgeting, inventory management, and cost control for food service.
Strong organizational skills, both at work and in personal life.
Experienced distance runner: understands training cycles, injury prevention, and race strategy.
Basic first aid and CPR certified.
Competent in using standard kitchen equipment and troubleshooting minor malfunctions.
Able to motivate and train new kitchen staff.
Experienced in organizing community events and church suppers.
Proficient in Microsoft Excel for menu planning and budgeting.
Basic gardening and food preservation (canning, freezing, pickling).
Knows how to repair and maintain small kitchen appliances.
Can sew and mend clothing, especially running gear.
Good at reading weather patterns for outdoor activities.
Able to create and follow detailed training plans for running.
Experienced in leading group runs and pacing others.
Can identify local flora and fauna.
Basic carpentry and home repair skills, learned from her father.

general: Wakes up at 4:45 AM to run before work, regardless of weather.
Prepares her running clothes and shoes the night before.
Logs every run in a paper journal, noting distance, pace, weather, and how she felt.
Checks the weather forecast multiple times a day.
Preps meals for the week on Sundays, labeling containers by day and meal.
Keeps a strict household budget, reviewing receipts weekly.
Attends church every Sunday and volunteers for coffee hour once a month.
Calls her mother every Thursday evening.
Sends birthday cards to extended family and friends.
Avoids eating out except for special occasions.
Walks the perimeter of her property every evening with her husband.
Volunteers at local races, handing out water or helping with registration.
Keeps her kitchen spotless, cleaning as she cooks.
Rarely watches TV except for the news and weather.
Shops for groceries with a detailed list, sticking to it closely.
Checks in on elderly neighbors, especially during bad weather.
Keeps a small emergency kit in her car and at home.
Prays before meals and at bedtime.
Avoids social media except for a private Facebook group for local runners.
Always brings a homemade dish to potlucks.

morning: 5-8 mile run on gravel roads, headlamp in winter.
Shower, then oatmeal with milk and a banana.
Prepares coffee for herself and her husband.
Checks her running log and reviews the day’s plan.
workday: Arrives at the assisted living center by 6:30 AM.
Meets with dietitian to review residents’ needs.
Lunch service at 11:30 AM, followed by cleanup.
Afternoon: menu planning, inventory, and paperwork.
evening: Walks with her husband and dog around the property.
Prepares a simple dinner (baked chicken, steamed vegetables, rice).
Prepares running gear for the next day.
Prays and reviews her gratitude journal.
weekend: Long run on Saturday mornings, sometimes with a local group.
Bakes bread or pastries for the week.
Gardens or does yard work in season.
Visits with children or grandchildren if they’re nearby.
Volunteers at community events or races.
Prepares meals for the week ahead.

health.physical: Generally good health for her age. Mild osteoarthritis in her right knee, managed with physical therapy and careful training. Occasional plantar fasciitis flare-ups. Slightly elevated cholesterol, controlled with diet and exercise. No major surgeries or hospitalizations. Maintains a healthy weight and blood pressure.
health.mental: Stable mood, low anxiety, and no history of depression. Uses running and prayer as primary stress management tools. Occasionally feels isolated during winter months, but maintains social connections through church and running group.
medical_history: Mild lactose intolerance, avoids large amounts of dairy.
Family history of type 2 diabetes and heart disease, motivating her healthy lifestyle.
Annual physicals and regular screenings, up to date on vaccinations.

family.name: Mark Swenson
family.description: Age 52, works as a farm equipment mechanic. Supportive of Linda’s running, often helps with race logistics. Enjoys fishing and woodworking.

family.name: Emily Swenson
family.description: Age 24, recently graduated from Iowa State University, now working as a nurse in Des Moines. Visits home monthly.

family.name: Jacob Swenson
family.description: Age 21, attending community college, lives at home part-time, helps with the family garden.

family.name: Ruth Johnson
family.description: Age 76, lives nearby, active in the same church. Linda calls her weekly and brings meals during illness.

friends.name: Karen Olson
friends.description: Running partner and fellow church member. They train together for local races and share recipes.

friends.name: Diane Miller
friends.description: Coworker at the assisted living center, often swaps shifts with Linda and shares gardening tips.

community.role: Active member, volunteers for events, occasionally leads prayer group.
Member, helps organize local races and group runs.

professional.name: Janet Peterson
professional.description: Dietitian at the assisted living center, collaborates on menu planning and resident care.

other_facts: Linda grew up on a dairy farm outside Decorah, learning the value of hard work from a young age.
She started running in her late 30s to manage stress and improve her health after her father’s heart attack.
Her first race was a local 5K, where she finished near the back but was inspired by the supportive atmosphere.
She has since completed 7 half-marathons and 2 full marathons, with a personal best of 4:12:37.
Linda keeps every race bib and medal in a shadow box in her living room.
She once sprained her ankle during a training run but still volunteered at the finish line of the race she had to skip.
Her favorite running route passes by three old barns and a small creek where she sometimes sees foxes.
She bakes a special batch of cinnamon rolls for her family every Christmas morning.
Linda’s kitchen is decorated with vintage Pyrex bowls inherited from her grandmother.
She has a small tattoo of a running shoe on her ankle, hidden from most people.
Linda and her husband built their own chicken coop and keep a flock of 8 hens.
She has a fear of snakes, stemming from a childhood encounter in the hayloft.
Linda’s favorite Bible verse is Philippians 4:13: 'I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.'
She once organized a charity run to raise money for a local family after a barn fire.
Linda’s favorite flower is the peony, which she grows along her driveway.
She has never traveled outside the Midwest, but dreams of visiting Norway to trace her family roots.
Linda keeps a handwritten recipe book, adding notes and modifications for each dish.
She is known for her dry sense of humor, often making puns about food or running.
Linda’s first car was a 1987 Chevy pickup, which she drove until it rusted out.
She has a collection of state fair ribbons for her bread and jam entries.
Linda once rescued a stray dog during a winter run; the dog, 'Buddy', is now part of the family.
She prefers paper maps to GPS and keeps an atlas in her car.
Linda’s favorite holiday is Thanksgiving, which she hosts for extended family every year.
She has a habit of humming hymns while cooking.
Linda is left-handed, but learned to use kitchen tools with her right hand.
She has a small scar on her left knee from a childhood fall off a hay wagon.
Linda’s favorite season is autumn, for the cool running weather and harvest festivals.
She once won a pie-eating contest at the county fair, but prefers to bake rather than eat sweets.
Linda’s favorite running shoes are Brooks Ghost, which she replaces every 400 miles.
She keeps a gratitude journal, writing three things she’s thankful for each night.
Linda’s biggest running fear is injury, so she is diligent about stretching and cross-training.
She has a standing bet with her husband: if she ever beats him at fishing, he’ll cook dinner for a week.
Linda’s favorite way to relax is sitting on the porch swing with a cup of coffee, watching the sunset.
She once got lost during a trail race and ended up running an extra two miles, but laughed it off.
Linda’s favorite childhood memory is making lefse with her grandmother every Christmas.
She is known for her calm presence during kitchen emergencies, keeping staff focused and safe.
Linda’s favorite local event is the Nordic Fest, where she volunteers at the food tent.
She has a small herb garden on her kitchen windowsill, used for cooking and tea.
Linda’s favorite book is 'The Little House on the Prairie' series, which she rereads every few years.
She keeps a running tally of miles run each year, aiming to increase it slightly each season.
